朱子語類：他又卻說： 「萬物皆備於我，不須外面求。 」 This sounds as if all the things of the world and the principles governing the world being clearly NOT found in oneself but remaining very much under investigation in terms of 格物, the expression 萬物 here, in this purely philosophical context, must perhaps extraordinarily be taken to refer to "all the (morally crucial) things are in oneself."
*Liang Hui Wang, Part 1*
1.1 Mencius had an audience with King Hui of Liang.
The King said,
"Old sir!
You have not thought it far to come a thousand *li*,
surely you must have something with which to profit my state?"
Mencius replied,
"Your Majesty! Why must you speak of profit?
All that matters is benevolence and righteousness.
If the King says,
'How can I profit my state?'
the high officials will say,
'How can I profit my family?'
and the officers and common people will say,
'How can I profit myself?'
When superiors and inferiors contend for profit
the state is endangered.
In a state of ten thousand chariots,
the one who assassinates its ruler
In a state of a thousand chariots,
the one who assassinates its ruler
will surely be from a family with a hundred chariots.
To take a thousand from ten thousand,
or a hundred from a thousand,
is not a small amount.
If righteousness is placed after profit,
Never robbing, never satisfied.
There has never been a benevolent person who abandoned their parents,
nor has there been a righteous person who put their ruler last.
Your Majesty should also speak of benevolence and righteousness,
why must you speak of profit?"
1.2 Mencius saw King Hui of Liang.
The King was standing by a pond,
looking at the swans, geese, deer, and elk,
and said:
"Do the wise also enjoy this?"
Mencius replied:
"Only the wise can truly enjoy this;
the unwise, even having it, do not enjoy it.
The *Book of Poetry* says:
'He planned the Spirit Tower,
planned and built it;
the common people worked on it,
and completed it in no time.
He started the plan without haste,
and the common people came like children.
The King is in the Spirit Park,
where the does lie down.
The does are sleek and fat,
the white birds are bright and numerous.
The King is in the Spirit Pond,
where the fish leap in abundance.'
King Wen used the people's labor to build the tower and the pond,
but the people rejoiced in it,
He called his terrace the "Spirit Terrace,"
and called his pond the "Spirit Pond,"
and delighted in having elk, deer, fish, and turtles.
The men of antiquity shared their pleasures with the people,
therefore they were able to be truly happy.
The "Oath of Tang" says:
'When will this sun perish?
I and you will all perish together!'
If the people desire to perish together with him,
even though he has terraces, ponds, birds, and beasts,
how can he be happy alone?"
1.3 King Hui of Liang said:
"In my dealings with the state,
I have exhausted my heart.
When there is famine in Henan,
I move its people to Hedong,
and move its grain to Henan.
When there is famine in Hedong,
I do the same.
Examining the governments of neighboring states,
there is no one who exerts himself as much as I do.
The populations of the neighboring states do not decrease,
and my population does not increase.
Why is this?"
Mencius replied:
"Your Majesty loves war;
allow me to use war as an analogy.
The drums roll thunderously,
"When weapons have already clashed,
they abandon their armor and drag their weapons as they flee.
Some stop after a hundred paces,
others stop after fifty paces.
Is it acceptable
to laugh at those who fled fifty paces at those who fled a hundred?"
He said:
"It is not acceptable;
it's just that they didn't reach a hundred paces,
they are still fleeing."
"If the king understands this,
then he will not expect his people to be more numerous than those of neighboring countries.
If you do not interfere with the farmers' planting seasons, then grain will be more than they can eat;
if nets with fine meshes are not allowed in pools and ponds, then fish and turtles will be more than they can eat;
if axes and hatchets are used in the mountains and forests at the proper times, then timber will be more than they can use.
When grain, fish and turtles are more than they can eat,
and timber is more than they can use,
then the people will be able to nurture their living and bury their dead without regret.
To nurture their living and bury their dead without regret
is the beginning of the Kingly Way.
On a homestead of five *mu*, if it is planted with mulberry trees,
those who are fifty years old can wear silk.
If the raising of chickens, pigs, dogs and swine is not missed at their proper times,
those who are seventy years old can eat meat.
If a hundred *mu* of fields are not deprived of their proper times,
then families of several mouths can be without hunger.
If the teachings of the schools and academies are carefully attended to,
and if they are further emphasized with the principles of filial piety and fraternal respect,
If you repeatedly emphasize the principles of filial piety and fraternal duty,
the gray-haired will not be carrying burdens on the roads.
Those who are seventy will be wearing silk and eating meat.
The common people will not be hungry or cold.
Yet, if you do not attain hegemony,
such a thing has never happened.
"Dogs and pigs eat the food of men and you do not know to restrain them.
There are corpses of the starved in the roads and you do not know to distribute grain.
When people die, you then say:
'It is not I, it is the year.'
How is this different from stabbing a man to death and saying:
'It is not I, it is the weapon.'
If Your Majesty does not blame the year,
then the people of the world will come to you."
1.4 King Hui of Liang said:
"I wish to respectfully receive your instruction."
Mencius replied:
"Is there any difference between killing a man with a club and with a knife?"
The King said:
"There is no difference."
Mencius asked: "Is there any difference between using a knife and using government?"
The King said: "There is no difference."
Mencius said:
"In the kitchen there is fat meat,
in the stables there are fat horses,
but the people have a hungry look,
In the fields there are starving corpses;
this is akin to leading beasts to devour men.
Beasts devouring each other
is something that people detest;
to be the father and mother of the people,
to govern, and yet be unable to avoid leading beasts to devour men,
how can one be considered the father and mother of the people?
Zhongni (Confucius) said:
'He who first made burial figures,
will probably have no descendants!'
Because he fashioned them in the likeness of men and used them.
How can
one allow the people to starve to death?"
1.5 King Hui of Liang said:
"The state of Jin
was the strongest in the world;
this is known to you, old man.
Since I have come to the throne,
we were defeated by Qi in the east,
and my eldest son died there;
in the west, we lost seven hundred *li* of land to Qin;
in the south, we were humiliated by Chu.
I am ashamed of this
and wish to avenge the dead in one fell swoop;
what should I do?"
Mencius replied:
"A territory of a hundred *li* square
is sufficient to become king.
If Your Majesty would implement benevolent governance for the people,
reduce punishments and penalties,
lighten taxes and levies,
promote deep plowing and careful weeding;
and allow the able-bodied to use their free time to cultivate filial piety, fraternal respect, loyalty, and trustworthiness;
at home, to serve their fathers and elder brothers;
and abroad, to serve their elders and superiors,
then they could be made to take up sticks to strike against the strong armor and sharp weapons of Qin and Chu.
"They deprive the people of their time,
preventing them from plowing and weeding
to support their parents.
Parents suffer from cold and hunger,
brothers, wives, and children are scattered.
They plunge their people into misery.
If Your Majesty goes forth to conquer them,
who will oppose Your Majesty?
Therefore, it is said:
'The benevolent are invincible.'
May Your Majesty please not doubt this!"
1.6 Mencius met with King Xiang of Liang.
After leaving,
he said to others,
"Looking at him, he does not resemble a ruler;
approaching him, one sees nothing to be feared.
He suddenly asked,
'How can the world be settled?'
"I replied,
'It will be settled through unification.'
“Who can unite it?”
He replied:
“He who does not delight in killing can unite it.”
“Who can support him?”
He replied:
“The whole world will support him.
Does Your Majesty know about seedlings?
In the seventh and eighth months, if there is a drought,
then the seedlings will wither.
When the sky suddenly makes clouds,
and the rain pours down,
then the seedlings will vigorously rise.
Being like this,
who can stop it?
Now, the shepherds of the people of the world,
there are none who do not delight in killing.
If there were one who did not delight in killing,
then the people of the world would all crane their necks and look to him.
If it is truly like this,
the people will return to him
as water flows downward;
how forcefully! Who could stop it?”
1.7 King Xuan of Qi asked,
"May I hear about the affairs of Duke Huan of Qi and Duke Wen of Jin?"
Mencius replied,
"Among the disciples of Confucius,
none spoke of the affairs of Dukes Huan and Wen.
Therefore, later generations have no transmission of them.
Therefore, that later generations have not transmitted it,
I have not heard of.
Without that, can one become a true king?"
He said:
"What kind of virtue
is necessary to become a true king?"
He said:
"To protect the people and become a true king,
none can resist it."
He said:
"Someone like me, can I protect the people?"
He said:
"Yes."
He said:
"How do you know that I can?"
He said:
"I heard Hu He say:
'The king was sitting in the hall,
and someone was leading an ox past the hall below.
The king saw it
and said:
"Where are you taking the ox?"
The man replied:
"We are going to use it to consecrate a bell."
The king said:
"Release it!
I cannot bear to see its trembling fear,
as if it were innocent and going to its death."
He replied,
"Then will the blood-anointing of the bell be abandoned?"
Mencius said,
"How can it be abandoned?
Substitute it with a sheep!"
I don't know if this is true?"
Mencius said,
"It is true."
He said,
"This heart is sufficient to become a king.
The common people all think that the King is being miserly,
but I knew that the King could not bear it."
The King said,
"Yes;
it is indeed the case that the people are there.
Although the state of Qi is small,
why would I begrudge a single ox?
It was simply that I could not bear its trembling appearance,
as if it were innocent and going to its death,
therefore I substituted it with a sheep."
Mencius said,
"The King should not be surprised that the people think that the King is being miserly.
Using something small to exchange for something big,
how would they know the reason for it?
If the King feels pain at seeing its innocence being brought to death,
then what difference is there between an ox and a sheep?"
The King laughed and said,
"Indeed, what is in my heart?
"It's not that I begrudged the expense and exchanged it for a sheep.
It is right that the people think I am stingy."
Mencius said:
"There's no harm in that.
This is precisely an act of benevolence.
You saw the ox, but you had not yet seen the sheep.
The attitude of a gentleman towards birds and beasts
is that, having seen them alive,
he cannot bear to see them die;
having heard their cries,
he cannot bear to eat their flesh.
That is why the gentleman keeps away from the kitchen."
The King was pleased and said:
"The Book of Poetry says:
'Other people have their minds,
I try to fathom them.'
That is what you are doing, Master.
I did indeed do it,
but upon reflection,
I could not understand my own heart.
What you say, Master,
resonates deeply with my heart.
What is the reason this heart of mine is consistent with that of a true king?"
Mencius said:
"Suppose someone were to report to Your Majesty, saying:
'My strength is sufficient to lift three thousand pounds,
but not sufficient to lift a feather;
my eyesight is sufficient to see the tip of an autumn hair,
and not see a cartload of firewood.'"
Would the king approve of that?"
He said,
"No."
"Now, your kindness is sufficient to reach birds and beasts,
but your meritorious deeds do not extend to the common people,
why is this the only thing?
Therefore, the failure to lift one feather
is because one does not use their strength;
the failure to see a cartload of firewood
is because one does not use their eyesight;
the failure to protect the common people
is because one does not use their kindness.
Therefore, that the king does not become a true king
is something he *does* not do,
it is not something he *cannot* do."
He said,
"How are the forms of that which one *does* not do and that which one *cannot* do
different?"
He said,
"To carry Mount Tai over the North Sea,
and tell someone,
'I cannot do it,'
that is truly something one *cannot* do.
To break off a branch for an elder,
and tell someone,
'I cannot do it,'
that is something one *does* not do,
It is not that one is unable to do it.
Therefore, a king's failure to become a true king
is not like carrying Mount Tai across the Northern Sea;
a king's failure to become a true king
is like breaking off a branch.
"Respect your elders, and extend that respect to the elders of others;
cherish your young, and extend that cherishing to the young of others.
The world can be moved within the palm of your hand."
The *Book of Poetry* says,
"He sets an example to his wife,
extends it to his brothers,
and thereby governs his family and state."
It means simply extending this heart of yours to others.
Therefore, extending kindness is enough to protect the whole world,
but failing to extend kindness makes it impossible to protect even one's wife and children.
The reason why the ancients greatly surpassed others
lies in nothing else
than being good at extending what they do.
Now, your kindness is sufficient to reach birds and beasts,
but your benefit does not reach the common people.
Why is this uniquely so?
"Weigh things, and then you know what is light and heavy;
measure things, and then you know what is long and short.
This is true of all things,
but especially true of the heart.
Your Majesty, please measure it!
"Or does Your Majesty raise troops,
"Is it that endangering your ministers and
incurring the hatred of the feudal lords
then brings satisfaction to your heart?"
The King said:
"No;
why would I find satisfaction in that?
I am doing it to obtain that which I greatly desire."
He said:
"May I be allowed to hear what it is that Your Majesty greatly desires?"
The King smiled but did not speak.
He said:
"Is it that rich foods are not sufficient for your palate?
Light and warm clothes are not sufficient for your body?
Or is it that bright colors are not sufficient for your eyes to see?
Sounds are not sufficient for your ears to hear?
Favored servants are not sufficient to command before you?
All of Your Majesty's ministers are sufficient to provide these things,
so surely Your Majesty is not doing it for these things?"
He said:
"No;
I am not doing it for these things."
He said:
"Then what Your Majesty greatly desires can be known already;
you desire to expand your territory,
have Qin and Chu come to court,
rule over the Central States
and pacify the surrounding barbarians.
"To use what you are doing to seek what you desire
is like climbing a tree to catch a fish."
The king said,
"Is it really that bad?"
He replied,
"It is probably worse.
Climbing a tree to catch a fish,
even if you don't get a fish,
there will be no later disaster.
Using what you are doing
to seek what you desire,
exhausting your heart and strength to do it,
there will surely be disaster later."
The king said,
"May I hear about it?"
He replied,
"If the people of Zou fought with the people of Chu,
who does Your Majesty think would win?"
The king said,
"The people of Chu would win."
He said,
"Therefore, a small state certainly cannot contend against a large state,
a few people certainly cannot contend against many people,
a weak state certainly cannot contend against a strong state.
The land within the seas
is nine squares, each a thousand *li*,
and Qi collectively possesses one of them.
To use one to subdue eight,
How is this different from Zou attacking Chu?
It is, in fact, turning away from the root.
"Now, if the King initiates benevolent governance,
making all scholars in the land desire to serve in the King's court,
all farmers desire to till the King's fields,
all merchants desire to store their goods in the King's markets,
all travelers desire to travel on the King's roads,
and all those in the land who wish to complain about their rulers
desire to flock to the King to plead their case.
If this is the case,
who can resist it?"
The King said,
"I am foolish
and unable to advance to this level.
I wish, Master, that you would assist my resolve
and clearly instruct me.
Although I am not clever,
I beg to try."
Mencius said,
"Those who lack permanent property but possess constant hearts,
only scholars are capable of this.
As for the common people, if they lack permanent property,
they will consequently lack constant hearts.
If they lack constant hearts,
they will indulge in licentiousness and extravagance,
and there is nothing they will not do.
And then, when they fall into crime,
you proceed to punish them;
This is ensnaring the people.
How could it be acceptable for a benevolent person to be in a position of authority
and yet ensnare the people?
Therefore, an enlightened ruler regulates the people's livelihood,
ensuring that, above, they have enough to support their parents,
and below, they have enough to raise their wives and children;
in good years, they are well-fed for life,
and in bad years, they are spared from death.
Then, they drive them towards goodness,
so the people follow them readily.
Now, in regulating the people's livelihood,
above, they do not have enough to support their parents,
and below, they do not have enough to raise their wives and children;
in good years, they suffer hardship for life,
and in bad years, they are not spared from death.
They are merely concerned with saving themselves from death, and fear that it will be insufficient.
How can they have the leisure to cultivate propriety and righteousness?
"If the king wishes to implement this,
then why not return to the root of the matter?
A homestead of five mu, planted with mulberry trees,
enables those of fifty to wear silk.
Raising chickens, pigs, dogs, and swine, without missing the proper time,
enables those of seventy to eat meat.
A field of one hundred mu, without depriving them of the proper time for cultivation,
enables a family of eight to be free from hunger.
Carefully attend to the education in schools and academies,
emphasizing the principles of filial piety and fraternal respect,
so that white-haired elders will not have to carry burdens on the roads.
“The old wear silk and eat meat,
the common people are not hungry or cold,
yet failing to become king,
such a case has never occurred.”
*Liang Hui Wang II*
2.1 Zhuang Bao saw Mencius and said,
"Bao had an audience with the king,
and the king spoke to Bao about his love of music,
but Bao had nothing to respond with."
Mencius said,
"What is this love of music like?"
Mencius said,
"If the king's love of music is great,
then the state of Qi will perhaps be close to being well-governed!"
Another day,
Mencius had an audience with the king and said,
"The king once spoke to Zhuangzi about his love of music,
is that so?"
The king changed color and said,
"I am not able to appreciate the music of the former kings;
I merely enjoy the popular music of the present day."
Mencius said,
"If the king's love of music is great,
then the state of Qi will perhaps be close to being well-governed!
The music of today is like the music of antiquity."
The king said,
"May I hear more about this?"
Said:
"To enjoy pleasure alone,
to enjoy pleasure with others,
which is more pleasurable?"
He said:
"Not as good as with others."
He said:
"To enjoy pleasure with a few,
to enjoy pleasure with many,
which is more pleasurable?"
He said:
"Not as good as with many."
Allow me, your servant, to explain pleasure to the king.
Now, if the king makes music here,
and the people hear the sound of the king's bells and drums,
and the sounds of pipes and flutes,
they will all hold their heads and knit their brows, and tell each other:
"Our king's love of music,
what has caused us to reach this extreme?
Fathers and sons do not see each other,
brothers, wives, and children are scattered."
Now, if the king hunts here,
and the people hear the sound of the king's chariots and horses,
and see the beauty of the feathered banners,
they will all hold their heads and knit their brows, and tell each other:
"Our king's love of hunting,
what has caused us to reach this extreme?
Fathers and sons do not see each other,
brothers and wives separated."
This is nothing other than
not sharing joy with the people.
"Now, if the King makes music here,
the people hear the sound of the King's bells and drums,
the tones of pipes and flutes,
and they all joyfully show delight and tell each other,
'Is our King perhaps without illness?
How else could he make music?'
Now, if the King hunts here,
the people hear the sound of the King's chariots and horses,
see the beauty of the feathered banners,
and they all joyfully show delight and tell each other,
'Is our King perhaps without illness?
How else could he hunt?'
This is nothing other than
sharing joy with the people.
Now, if the King shares joy with the people, then he will be a true king."
2.2 King Xuan of Qi asked,
"King Wen's park was seventy li square,
is that so?"
Mencius replied,
"It is recorded in the traditions."
The King said,
"Was it really that large?"
Mencius said,
"The people still thought it was small."
Said:
"My park is forty li square,
yet the people still think it is large,
why is that?"
Said:
"King Wen's park was seventy li square,
those who gathered grass and firewood went there,
pheasant and rabbit hunters went there,
he shared it with the people.
The people thought it was small,
is that not fitting?
When I first arrived at the border,
I inquired about the greatest prohibitions of the state,
and only then dared I enter.
I have heard that within the suburban borders
there is a park forty li square,
those who kill its deer
are punished as if they had killed a man.
Then this forty li square is a trap in the middle of the country.
The people think it is large, is that not fitting?"
2.3 King Xuan of Qi asked, saying:
"Is there a way to deal with neighboring countries?"
Mencius replied, saying:
"There is.
Only the benevolent are able to serve the small with the great,
therefore Tang served Ge,
and King Wen served the Hunyi.
Only the wise are able to serve the great with the small,
Therefore, the Great King served the Xunyu,
and Goujian served Wu.
Those who serve smaller states with larger ones are those who delight in Heaven;
those who serve larger states with smaller ones are those who fear Heaven.
Those who delight in Heaven preserve the world,
those who fear Heaven preserve their state.
The *Book of Poetry* says:
"Fearing the awesomeness of Heaven,
thereby preserve it."
The King said:
"Great are these words!
I have a fault,
I am fond of bravery."
He replied:
"May the King please not be fond of small bravery.
Brandishing a sword and glaring fiercely, saying:
'How dare they stand against me!'
This is the bravery of a common man,
one who can defeat a single person.
May the King please make it great!
The *Book of Poetry* says:
'The King was greatly angered,
thereby he organized his troops,
to stop the departing Ju,
to strengthen the Zhou blessings,
to respond to the world.'
This is the bravery of King Wen.
King Wen, once angered,
and pacify the people of the world.
The *Book of Documents* says:
"Heaven sent down the people,
and made for them rulers,
and made for them teachers,
intending only that they should assist God and cherish them.
If those in all quarters have committed offenses, the blame rests on me alone,
who would dare to go beyond my will?"
When one man acted tyrannically in the world,
King Wu felt ashamed.
This was the courage of King Wu.
And King Wu, with a single display of anger,
pacified the people of the world.
Now, Your Majesty, with a single display of anger,
can also pacify the people of the world.
The people are only afraid that Your Majesty does not like courage."
2.4 King Xuan of Qi saw Mencius at the Xue Palace.
The King said:
"Do worthy men also have this kind of pleasure?"
Mencius replied:
"Yes.
If the people do not have it,
then they blame their superiors.
To blame their superiors when they do not have it
is wrong;
to be the ruler of the people and not share joy with the people
is also wrong.
One who delights in the joy of the people,
the people will also delight in their joy.
One who grieves at the sorrow of the people,
the people will also grieve at their sorrow.
To find joy with the whole world,
to grieve with the whole world,
and yet not become king,
there has never been such a case.
"In the past, Duke Jing of Qi asked Yan Zi, saying:
'I wish to view the "Zhuan Fu Zhao Wu",
following the coast southward,
ending at Langya.
What should I cultivate in order to be compared to the inspections of the former kings?'"
"Yan Zi replied, saying:
'An excellent question!
When the Son of Heaven goes to the feudal lords, it is called a "Patrol Hunt."
"Patrol Hunt" means inspecting what is being guarded.
When the feudal lords pay court to the Son of Heaven, it is called "Reporting Duties."
"Reporting Duties" means reporting on what has been done.
There is nothing that is not a matter of business.
In the spring, he inspects the plowing and makes up for deficiencies;
in the autumn, he inspects the harvest and aids those in need.
There is a summer saying:
"If our king does not travel,
how can we rest?
If our king does not enjoy himself,
how can we help him?"
"One tour and one hunt
is a model for the feudal lords."
But now it is not so:
When the army marches, it carries its own provisions;
The hungry are not fed,
The weary are not rested.
They glare at each other and slander,
And the people then do evil.
They defy orders and mistreat the people,
And their eating and drinking is like a flowing stream.
Indulging in pleasures and abandoning themselves to dissipation,
They cause worry for the feudal lords.
To follow the stream downward and forget to return
is called "flowing";
To follow the stream upward and forget to return
is called "lingering";
To hunt animals without satiety
is called "dissipation";
To enjoy wine without satiety
is called "ruin."
The former kings had no pleasures of lingering and flowing,
No conduct of dissipation and ruin.
It is only what the ruler does."
Duke Jing was pleased
and issued a great warning throughout the state,
Moving out to reside in the suburbs.
Thereupon, he began to initiate distribution and make up for deficiencies.
He summoned the Grand Musician and said:
"Compose for me music depicting the relationship between ruler and minister!"
This refers to the pieces "Zhi Zhao" and "Jiao Zhao."
The poem says:
"What blame is there in cherishing the ruler?"
"Cherishing the ruler"
means "being fond of the ruler."
2.5 King Xuan of Qi asked,
"Everyone says I should destroy the Ming Tang (Bright Hall).
Should I destroy it? Or should I stop?"
Mencius replied,
"The Ming Tang is the hall of a true king.
If Your Majesty wishes to practice kingly government,
then do not destroy it."
The King said,
"May I hear about kingly government?"
Mencius replied,
"In the past, when King Wen governed Qi,
farmers paid a tax of one-ninth,
officials received hereditary stipends,
the border markets were inspected but not taxed,
there were no restrictions on ponds and weirs,
and the families of criminals were not implicated.
An old man without a wife is called a widower;
an old woman without a husband is called a widow;
an old person without children is called solitary;
a young person without a father is called an orphan.
These four are
the poor people of the world who have no one to turn to.
When King Wen initiated his government and implemented benevolence,
he invariably prioritized these four things.
The *Book of Poetry* says,
'Admirable are the wealthy,
Pitiable are the solitary and alone.' "
The King said:
"Well said!"
Mencius said:
"If the King approves of this,
then why not put it into practice?"
The King said:
"I have a failing;
I am fond of wealth."
Mencius replied:
"In the past, Duke Liu was fond of wealth.
The *Book of Poetry* says:
'Then he accumulated stores and filled granaries,
Then he wrapped up dried provisions,
In sacks and in bags.
He thought of storing away for future use to enhance his glory.
Bows and arrows were readied,
Shields and spears, axes and halberds were brandished,
And thereupon they set out.'
Therefore, those who stayed behind had stores and granaries,
Those who traveled had wrapped bags of provisions,
Only then could they 'thereupon set out'.
If the King is fond of wealth,
share it with the people,
What difficulty is there for the king?"
The king said,
"I have a fault,
I am fond of women."
The reply was,
"Formerly, Great King Danfu was fond of women,
and loved his concubine.
The *Book of Poetry* says,
'Ancient Duke Danfu, in the morning came galloping his horse,
along the banks of the western river, until he came to the foot of Mount Qi,
and with Jiang Nu, he came to survey their house.'
At that time,
within there were no resentful women,
and without there were no unmarried men.
If the king is fond of women,
and shares this fondness with the people,
what difficulty is there for the king?"
2.6 Mencius said to King Xuan of Qi,
"Suppose one of your majesty’s ministers were to entrust his wife and children to the care of his friend
and go to Chu on a journey.
When he returns,
he finds that his wife and children have been allowed to suffer from cold and hunger.
What should he do in such a case?"
The king said,
"Dismiss him."
Mencius said,
"If the chief criminal judge cannot govern the officers under him,
what should be done?"
The king said,
"Enough."
Mencius said,
"If the realm within your borders is not well-governed,
what then?"
The king looked to his attendants and spoke of other matters.
2.7 Mencius had an audience with King Xuan of Qi, and said,
"What is meant by 'an old state'
does not refer to having tall trees;
it refers to having ministers who have served for generations.
You, O king, have no loyal ministers.
Those you formerly promoted
today you do not even know have fled."
The king said,
"How can I recognize their lack of talent and dismiss them?"
Mencius said,
"A ruler advancing the worthy should act as if he has no choice.
It will lead to the lowly surpassing the high,
and the distant surpassing the close relatives.
Can one not be cautious in this?
If those around you all say they are worthy,
it is not yet acceptable;
if all the high officials say they are worthy,
it is not yet acceptable;
if all the people of the state say they are worthy,
then examine them;
when you see they are indeed worthy,
Then employ it.
If those on the left and right all say it is not permissible,
do not listen;
if all the high officials say it is not permissible,
do not listen;
if all the people of the state say it is not permissible,
then examine it;
if you see that it is indeed not permissible,
then abandon it.
If those on the left and right all say he is fit to be killed,
do not listen;
if all the high officials say he is fit to be killed,
do not listen;
if all the people of the state say he is fit to be killed,
then examine it;
if you see that he is indeed fit to be killed,
then kill him.
Therefore, it is said: the people of the state killed him.
In this way,
then one can be the parent of the people."
2.8 King Xuan of Qi asked,
"Tang banished Jie,
King Wu attacked Zhou,
is this true?"
Mencius replied,
"It exists in the records."
The King said,
"A minister murdering his ruler,
Is that permissible?"
Mencius replied:
is called 'a mere fellow'.
I have heard of the execution of the mere fellow, Zhou,
but I have not heard of a subject murdering his ruler."
2.9 Mencius said to King Xuan of Qi:
"When building a great house,
one must employ a master carpenter to find large timbers.
When the master carpenter finds large timbers,
the king rejoices,
thinking that he is capable of the task.
But if a craftsman carves them down to make them smaller,
the king will be angry,
thinking that he is not capable of the task.
Now, a person learns something in their youth,
and desires to put it into practice when they are grown.
If the king says,
'For now, put aside what you have learned and follow me,'
what would that be like?
Now, if there were a piece of uncut jade here,
even if it were worth ten thousand yi,
one would surely employ a jade artisan to carve and polish it.
But when it comes to governing the state,
Then he would say:
"Put aside what you have learned and follow me."
In what way would this differ from teaching a jade artisan to carve jade?"
2.10 The people of Qi attacked Yan and were victorious.
King Xuan asked:
"Some advise me not to take it,
and some advise me to take it.
With a state of ten thousand chariots attacking a state of ten thousand chariots,
conquering it in fifty days,
human strength alone could not achieve this.
If I do not take it, there will surely be heavenly calamity.
What if I take it?"
Mencius replied:
"If the people of Yan are pleased by taking it,
then take it.
Among the ancients, there was one who did this,
King Wu.
If the people of Yan are not pleased by taking it,
then do not take it.
Among the ancients, there was one who did this,
King Wen.
With a state of ten thousand chariots attacking a state of ten thousand chariots,
the people offer baskets of food and pitchers of drink to welcome the king's army.
What other reason could there be?
They are escaping water and fire.
If the water becomes deeper,
if the fire becomes hotter,
it is merely a change of fortune."
2.11 The people of Qi attacked Yan and
captured it.
The feudal lords were about to plot to rescue Yan.
King Xuan said:
"Many of the feudal lords are plotting to attack me, the solitary one.
How should I deal with them?"
Mencius replied:
"I have heard that one who governs the world with seventy li of land is Tang.
I have never heard of one who fears others because of a thousand li of land.
The *Book* says:
'Tang began his first campaign
from Ge.'
The world believed in him.
When he campaigned to the east,
the Western barbarians resented it;
when he campaigned to the south,
the Northern barbarians resented it,
saying:
'Why am I put last?'
The people looked to him
as one looks to clouds and rainbows in a great drought.
Those returning to market did not stop,
and those plowing did not change their ways.
He executed their ruler and consoled their people,
like timely rain falling.
The people were greatly pleased.
The *Book* says:
“We wait for our ruler,
when our ruler arrives, we will be revived.”
Now, Yan maltreats its people,
and the king goes to conquer it.
The people think that he will rescue them from water and fire,
and bring baskets of food and pots of drink to welcome the king’s army.
If he kills their fathers and elder brothers,
imprisons their sons and younger brothers,
destroys their ancestral temples,
moves their precious treasures,
how can that be permissible?
The world certainly fears the strength of Qi,
and now it has doubled its territory
but does not practice benevolent government.
This is to incite the armies of the world.
The king should quickly issue an order
to return their old and young,
stop the removal of their precious treasures,
consult with the people of Yan,
establish a ruler, and then leave.
Then it will still be possible to stop it.”
2.12 Zou and Lu were at war.
Duke Mu asked,
“My officers have died, thirty-three men,
but the people did not die for them.
To punish them
would be more than can be punished;
not to punish them
Then, to watch with indifference the death of their superiors without offering aid –
how can this be permissible?"
Mencius replied,
"In years of famine and scarcity,
your lord's people, the old and weak, are abandoned in ditches and gullies,
and the strong scatter and go to the four corners of the land, numbering in the thousands;
yet your lord's granaries are full,
and the treasuries overflowing.
None of the officials report this,
this is negligence and cruelty towards those below.
Zengzi said,
'Be cautious! Be cautious!
What comes forth from you
will return to you.'
Now the people are finally able to return it.
Your lord has no one to blame!
If your lord practices benevolent governance,
the people will cherish their superiors
and die for their leaders."
2.13 Duke Wen of Teng asked,
"Teng is a small state,
situated between Qi and Chu.
Should I serve Qi?
Should I serve Chu?"
Mencius replied,
"This plan is not within my ability to advise.
If there is no alternative,
then there is one course:
"If you dig this pond,
and build this city,
and defend it together with the people,
and they are willing to die for it and not leave,
then it is something that can be done."
2.14 Duke Wen of Teng asked,
"The people of Qi are about to build Xue,
and I am very afraid.
What should I do?"
Mencius replied,
"In the past, King Da lived in Bin,
and the Di people invaded him.
He left and lived at the foot of Mount Qi.
It was not a matter of choosing,
but of being forced to.
If you do good,
your descendants will surely have a king.
A gentleman establishes a foundation and establishes a tradition,
for it to be continued.
As for success,
that is up to Heaven.
What can you do about it?
Just strive to do good."
2.15 Duke Wen of Teng asked,
"Teng is a small state;
if I exhaust my strength to serve the large state,
I will not be able to avoid trouble.
What should I do?"
Mencius replied,
"In the past, when King Da lived in Bin,
the Di people invaded.
He served them with furs and silks,
but was not spared;
he served them with dogs and horses,
but was not spared;
he served them with pearls and jade,
but was not spared.
Then he gathered his elders and announced to them, saying,
'What the Di people desire is our land.
I have heard it said:
A gentleman does not use that by which he nourishes people to harm them.
Why should you gentlemen worry about not having a ruler?
I shall depart from here.'
He left Bin, crossed Mount Liang,
and settled at the foot of Mount Qi.
The people of Bin said,
'He is a benevolent man,
we must not lose him.'
Those who followed him were like people returning to a marketplace.
Someone said,
'It is a hereditary possession,
not something one can decide for oneself.
Let us fight to the death and not leave.'
"I ask you to choose between these two options."
2.16 Duke Ping of Lu was about to go out,
A favorite retainer named Zang Cang requested, saying:
"In the past, when the ruler went out,
he would always instruct the officials where he was going.
Now the carriage is already prepared,
but the officials do not know where you are going.
May I ask?"
The Duke said:
"I am going to see Mencius."
Zang Cang said:
"Why is it that Your Lordship lowers yourself to prioritize a commoner?
Do you consider him virtuous?
Etiquette and righteousness originate from the virtuous;
yet Mencius' family's later funerals exceed the earlier ones in extravagance.
Your Lordship should not see him!"
The Duke said:
"Alright."
Yue Zhengzi entered to see the Duke and said:
"Why is it that Your Lordship will not see Mencius?"
The Duke said:
"Someone told me:
'Mencius' family's later funerals exceed the earlier ones in extravagance,'
therefore I am not going to see him."
Yue Zhengzi said:
"What does Your Lordship mean by 'exceed'?
Was it that the first funeral was for a scholar, and the later one for a high official?
Or that the first used three tripods, and the later used five tripods?"
The Duke said:
"No;
This refers to the excellence of coffins, outer coffins, clothing, and shrouds. 」
He said:
「This is not what is called excess;
it is simply that the rich and poor are different. 」
Le Zhengzi saw Mencius and said:
「I told the ruler that
you would come to see him.
But the ruler was dissuaded by a favorite, Zang Cang,
and that is why he did not come. 」
Mencius said:
「To proceed or be made to proceed, there are those who cause it;
to stop or be made to stop, there are those who hinder it.
Proceeding or stopping is not something people can control.
My failure to meet the Marquis of Lu
is Heaven's will.
How could the son of Zang
possibly prevent me from meeting him? 」
*Gongsun Chou (Part 1)*
3.1 Gongsun Chou asked,
「If you were in a position of power in Qi,
could you promise to repeat the achievements of Guan Zhong and Yan Zi? 」
Mencius said,
「You are indeed a man of Qi,
knowing only Guan Zhong and Yan Zi.
Someone asked Zeng Xi:
'Who is more virtuous, you or Zilu?'
Zeng Xi became startled and said,
"He was someone my late father held in awe."
He said,
"In that case, which is more virtuous, you or Guan Zhong?"
Zeng Xi looked displeased and said,
"How can you compare me to Guan Zhong?
Guan Zhong had a ruler who trusted him so completely,
he carried out the state's policies for so long,
and his accomplishments were so meager.
How can you compare me to him in these respects?"
He said,
"Guan Zhong is someone Zeng Xi would not emulate,
and yet you want me to aspire to be like him?"
He said,
"Guan Zhong made his ruler a hegemon,
and Yanzi made his ruler illustrious.
Are Guan Zhong and Yanzi still not sufficient examples?"
He said,
"Becoming a true king with the state of Qi,
is as easy as turning one's hand."
He said,
"If that's the case,
then my confusion only deepens.
Furthermore, with King Wen's virtue,
he died after a hundred years,
and his influence still did not fully extend throughout the world.
King Wu and the Duke of Zhou succeeded him,
and then his influence greatly spread.
Now you speak of becoming a true king as if it were easy,
Then is King Wen not worth emulating?"
Mencius said:
"How can King Wen be compared?
From Tang to Wu Ding,
six or seven wise and sagely rulers arose.
The world had belonged to Yin for a long time,
and what has lasted long is difficult to change.
When Wu Ding held court for the feudal lords,
possessing the empire was like turning it in his palm.
Not long had passed since Zhou's time compared to Wu Ding's,
so the old families, remaining customs, flowing influence, and good governance, still had some remaining;
furthermore, there were Wei Zi, Wei Zhong, Prince Bi Gan, Ji Zi, and Jiao Ge,
all worthy men,
who assisted each other,
therefore it was only after a long time that he lost it.
Not an inch of land was not in his possession;
not a single person was not his subject;
yet King Wen still started with only a hundred square li,
and that is why it was difficult.
The people of Qi have a saying:
'Though one has wisdom,
it is not as good as seizing opportunity;
though one has a mattock,
it is not as good as waiting for the right time.'
Now the time is easy indeed:
In the height of Xia, Yin, and Zhou,
their territory never exceeded a thousand li,
and Qi already has that territory;
The sounds of chickens crowing and dogs barking can be heard by each other,
reaching all four borders,
and Qi will possess its people.
The land will not need to be newly opened up,
the people will not need to be newly gathered,
practice benevolent government, and you will become king,
and none will be able to resist you.
Moreover, the non-appearance of a true king
has never been more needed than at this time;
the people's suffering under cruel government
has never been greater than at this time.
Those who are hungry are easily fed,
those who are thirsty are easily given drink.
Confucius said:
'The spreading of virtue
is faster than sending messengers by post to deliver orders.'
At this present time,
if a state of ten thousand chariots practices benevolent government,
the people will rejoice,
as if being rescued from being hung upside down.
Therefore, accomplishing the same deeds as the people of ancient times,
the achievement will certainly be doubled,
only at this time is that so."
3.2 Gongsun Chou asked, "
If you, Master, were to become the minister of Qi,
and were able to implement your Way,
then even becoming a hegemon or true king from this would not be different.
In such a case, would your heart be moved?"
Mencius said,
"No;
at forty, I achieved an unmoved mind."
Someone said,
"If that is the case,
then you surpass Meng Ben by far."
Mencius said,
"This is not difficult.
Gaozi was unmoved in mind before I was."
The other said,
"Is there a method to achieve an unmoved mind?"
Mencius said,
"Yes.
Beigong You's way of cultivating courage was this:
He would not allow his skin to yield,
nor his eyes to evade.
If he thought he might be defeated by even a hair's breadth,
he would consider it as being flogged in the marketplace.
He would not accept deference from a common man in coarse clothing,
nor would he accept it from the ruler of ten thousand chariots.
He viewed stabbing the ruler of ten thousand chariots
as if he were stabbing a commoner.
He showed no awe of the feudal lords.
When harsh words came to him,
he would certainly retort.
Meng Shishe's way of cultivating courage was this:
He said,
'To regard defeat as victory;
To measure the enemy before advancing,
to consider victory before engaging,
this is to fear the army.
How can he be sure to win by abandoning [such caution]?
He can only be without fear. 』
Meng Shishe resembled Zengzi,
Beigong You resembled Zixia.
As for the courage of these two men,
I do not know which is superior,
but Meng Shishe adhered to the superficial.
Formerly, Zengzi said to Zixiang,
"Do you like courage?
I once heard of great courage from the Master:
If, upon reflection, I find myself in the wrong,
even though [my opponent] wears coarse clothing and a wide belt,
I will be apprehensive.
If, upon reflection, I find myself in the right,
even against ten million people, I will go forward."
Meng Shishe's guarding of his qi [vital energy],
is also not as good as Zengzi's guarding of the essential principle."
[He] said:
"May I venture to ask
about the Master's freedom from perturbation and Gaozi's freedom from perturbation?
Can I be allowed to hear about them?"
"Gaozi said:
'If you cannot obtain it from words,
do not seek it in your heart;
if you cannot obtain it in your heart,
Do not seek it in the *qi*.
If you do not obtain it in your heart,
do not seek it in the *qi*;
that is acceptable.
If you do not obtain it in words,
do not seek it in your heart;
that is not acceptable.
The will is the commander of the *qi*,
and the *qi* is the filling of the body.
The will is the most important;
the *qi* is secondary.
Therefore, it is said:
'Hold fast to your will,
do not be violent with your *qi*.'"
"You have already said, 'The will is the most important;
the *qi* is secondary.'
Now you say,
'Hold fast to your will,
do not be violent with your *qi*.'
What does this mean?"
He replied,
"When the will is focused, it moves the *qi*;
when the *qi* is focused, it moves the will.
Consider those who stumble and those who rush;
this is the *qi*,
and yet it moves their minds in the opposite direction."
"May I ask, in what does Master excel?"
He said,
"I understand words;
I am good at nurturing my vast, flowing qi."
"May I ask, what is vast, flowing qi?"
He said:
"It's difficult to explain.
As for this qi,
it is supremely great and supremely strong.
If it is nourished directly without harm,
then it fills the space between heaven and earth.
As for this qi,
it is matched with righteousness and the Way;
without these, it will be feeble.
It is produced by the accumulation of righteous deeds,
it is not something to be seized by an attack on righteousness.
If one's conduct is not satisfying to the heart,
then it will be feeble."
Therefore I said:
"Gaozi never understood righteousness,
because he treated it as external.
There must be work to be done,
but do not try to force it.
The mind should not forget it,
but do not help it grow artificially.
Do not be like the man of Song:
There was a man of Song who worried that his seedlings were not growing, so he pulled them up.
Exhausted, he returned home,
saying to his family,
"Today I am ill!
I have been helping the seedlings grow!"
His son hurried to go and look at them,
and the seedlings were withered.
Those in the world who do not help the seedlings grow are few.
Those who think it is of no benefit and abandon them
are those who do not weed the seedlings;
those who help them grow
are those who pull up the seedlings.
Not only is it of no benefit,
but it also harms them.
"What is meant by 'understanding language'?"
He said:
"Biased words, one knows what they conceal;
excessive words, one knows what they trap;
heretical words, one knows what they depart from;
evasive words, one knows where they are exhausted.
If they arise in the heart,
they harm the government;
if they are expressed in government,
they harm affairs.
Even if a sage were to rise again,
he would surely follow my words."
"Zai Wo and Zigong were good at eloquent speech;
Ran Niu, Min Zi, and Yan Yuan were good at speaking about virtue and conduct.
Confucius combined both,
He said,
"As for eloquent pronouncements,
I am incapable of that."
"Then, are you, Master, already a sage?"
He said,
"Alas!
What are you saying?
In the past, Zigong asked Confucius, saying,
'Master, are you a sage?'
Confucius said,
'Sage, I am incapable of that.
I simply learn without being satiated and teach without being weary.'
Zigong said,
'Learning without being satiated is wisdom;
teaching without being weary is benevolence.
Being both benevolent and wise,
Master, you are already a sage.'
Even the sage Confucius did not claim that status,
what are you saying?"
"In the past, I have heard it said:
Zixia, Ziyou, and Zizhang
each possessed one aspect of a sage;
Ran Niu, Minzi, and Yan Yuan
possessed the complete body but in a subtle way.
May I ask where you place yourself?"
He said,
"Let's put that aside for now."
He said,
"Let us put this aside."
He said:
"What about Bo Yi and Yi Yin?"
He said:
"They followed different paths.
He would not serve a ruler who was not his,
nor would he employ people who were not his;
when there was good government, he advanced;
when there was disorder, he withdrew; this was Bo Yi.
Why must he serve only his ruler,
why must he only employ his people?
When there was good government, he advanced;
when there was disorder, he advanced; this was Yi Yin.
When one can serve, then serve;
when one can retire, then retire;
when one can stay long, then stay long;
when one can leave quickly, then leave quickly; this was Confucius.
All were ancient sages,
but I have not been able to act like them;
what I wish,
is to learn from Confucius."
"Are Bo Yi and Yi Yin ranked in the same class as Confucius?"
He said:
"No;
since the beginning of humankind,
there has not been a Confucius."
"Then are there any similarities?"
He said:
Since the beginning of humankind,
there has never been a Confucius."
"Then are there similarities?"
He said:
"Yes.
If given a hundred square li of land to rule,
they could all command the feudal lords and possess the empire;
to commit one unrighteous act,
to kill one innocent person,
in order to gain the empire,
they would all not do it.
In this they are the same."
He said:
"May I ask where they differ?"
He said:
"Zai Wo, Zi Gong, and You Ruo,
their wisdom was sufficient to know a sage,
and they would not stoop to flatter his preferences.
Zai Wo said:
"As I see it, regarding the Master,
he is far more virtuous than Yao and Shun."
Zi Gong said:
"Seeing his rites, one knows his government;
hearing his music, one knows his virtue;
even after a hundred generations,
he will be equal to the kings of a hundred generations,
and none will be able to go against him.
Since the beginning of humankind,
There had not been a Master yet."
You Ruo said:
"How can it be only about the people?
The unicorn is to running beasts,
the phoenix is to flying birds,
Mount Tai is to mounds and ant-hills,
and the Yellow River and the seas are to rain-puddles –
they are all of the same kind.
The sage is to the people
also of the same kind.
He emerges from his kind,
rises above the multitude.
Since the creation of mankind,
there has not been one more eminent than Confucius."
3.3 Mencius said:
"He who uses force to feign benevolence is a hegemon;
a hegemon must possess a great state.
He who practices benevolence through virtue is a true king;
a true king need not be great;
Tang rose to power with seventy *li*,
King Wen with one hundred *li*.
"He who subdues people with force
does not win their hearts;
it is because his strength is insufficient.
He who subdues people with virtue
wins their heartfelt and sincere submission,
as the seventy disciples submitted to Confucius.
The Book of Odes says:
“From west, from east,
from south, from north,
none but submit.”
This is what it means."
3.4 Mencius said:
"Benevolence leads to honor,
lack of benevolence leads to disgrace.
To dislike disgrace yet dwell in lack of benevolence
is like disliking dampness yet dwelling in a low-lying place.
If you truly dislike it,
there is nothing better than valuing virtue and respecting scholars,
having the worthy in positions of authority,
and the capable in positions of responsibility.
When the state is at peace,
seize the opportunity to clarify its governance and laws.
Even large states
will surely fear it.
The Book of Odes says:
'While the sky is not yet cloudy and rainy,
let us strip those mulberry roots,
and carefully repair the windows and doors.
Now, who among these people
would dare to insult me?'
Confucius said:
'The author of this poem,
truly understands the Way!
Being able to govern his state well,
who would dare to insult him?'
Now that the state is at leisure,
if at this time we indulge in pleasure and idleness,
it is to seek disaster for ourselves.
There is no misfortune or happiness that is not sought by oneself.
The *Book of Poetry* says:
"Always conform to Heaven's mandate,
and seek abundant blessings for yourself."
The *Tai Jia* says:
"Calamities sent by Heaven
may still be avoided;
calamities brought on by oneself
cannot be survived."
This is what it means."
3.5 Mencius said:
"If the worthy are honored and the able are employed,
and outstanding men are in office,
then all the scholars in the world will be pleased and wish to stand in his court.
If markets and shops are not taxed,
and the laws do not tax shop sites,
then all the merchants in the world will be pleased and wish to store their goods in his markets.
If customs houses and inspection stations do not tax,
then all the travelers in the world will be pleased and wish to go out on his roads.
If farmers are assisted and not taxed,
then all the farmers in the world will be pleased and wish to cultivate his fields.
If there are no taxes on shop sites or levies on village land,
then all the people in the world will be pleased and wish to be his subjects.
If one can truly practice these five things,
then the people of neighboring states will look up to him as to their parents.
"Leading their sons and younger brothers to attack their parents –
since the beginning of humankind, there has never been anyone who could succeed in that.
If you do this,
then you will be without equal in the world.
He who is without equal in the world is an officer of Heaven.
And yet, that he does not become king –
that has never happened."
3.6 Mencius said,
"All men have a mind which cannot bear to see the suffering of others.
The former kings had a mind which could not bear to see the suffering of others,
and hence they had government which could not bear to see the suffering of the people.
With a mind that cannot bear to see the suffering of others,
to practice government that cannot bear to see the suffering of others,
governing the world will be as easy as moving something on the palm of your hand.
The reason why I say that all men have a mind that cannot bear to see the suffering of others is this:
Suppose a man were suddenly to see a child about to fall into a well;
he would without exception experience a feeling of alarm and distress.
It is not for the sake of gaining the favor of the child’s parents that he would do this;
it is not for the sake of seeking praise from his neighbors and friends;
and it is not because he dislikes the sound of the child’s crying that he would do this.
From this, we can see that
a man without the feeling of commiseration
is not a man;
a man without the feeling of shame and dislike
is not a man;
a man without the feeling of deference and compliance
is not a man;
a man without the feeling of right and wrong
is not human.
The heart of compassion is the beginning of benevolence;
the heart of shame and dislike is the beginning of righteousness;
the heart of deference and yielding is the beginning of propriety;
the heart of right and wrong is the beginning of wisdom.
That man possesses these four beginnings
is like having four limbs.
To possess these four beginnings and then say that one is incapable is
to injure oneself.
To say that one's ruler is incapable is
to injure one's ruler.
Whoever has these four beginnings in himself
knows that he should expand and fill them out.
It is like a fire just beginning to burn,
or a spring just beginning to flow.
If one can fill them out,
it will be enough to protect the whole world.
If one cannot fill them out,
it will not be enough to serve one's parents."
3.7 Mencius said,
"Is the arrow maker not less benevolent than the armor maker?
The arrow maker is only afraid of not hurting people,
the armor maker is only afraid of hurting people.
The shaman and craftsman are also like this.
Therefore, one cannot but be careful about one's occupation.
Confucius said,
'It is good to dwell in benevolence.
If one chooses not to dwell in benevolence,
How can one obtain wisdom?’”
Now, benevolence is the honored title conferred by Heaven,
and the peaceful dwelling place of man.
If one is unrestrained and not benevolent,
this is unwise.
To be without benevolence and without wisdom,
without propriety and without righteousness,
is to be a servant of others.
To be a servant of others and yet be ashamed of being a servant,
is like a bow-maker being ashamed of making bows,
or an arrow-maker being ashamed of making arrows.
If you are ashamed of this,
there is nothing better than to practice benevolence.
The benevolent are like archers:
archers correct themselves before shooting;
if they shoot and do not hit the target,
they do not resent those who have surpassed them,
but turn and seek the cause within themselves.”
3.8 Mencius said:
“When Zilu was told that he had faults, he rejoiced.
When Yu heard good words, he bowed.
Great Shun was even greater,
he shared goodness with others,
abandoning himself to follow others,
gladly taking goodness from others and making it his own.
From plowing and sowing, pottery, and fishing,
to becoming emperor,
are no more than taking from others.
To take from others and consider it good
is to do good with others.
Therefore, for a gentleman, there is nothing greater than doing good with others."
3.9 Mencius said:
"Bo Yi would not serve a ruler who was not his own,
nor would he befriend someone who was not his friend.
He would not stand in the court of an evil person,
nor would he speak with an evil person.
Standing in the court of an evil person
and speaking with an evil person
would be like sitting in ceremonial robes and cap amidst mud and charcoal.
Extending his aversion to evil,
desiring to stand with villagers,
if their caps were not straight,
he would look at them intently and leave,
as if he were about to be sullied.
Therefore, even if feudal lords came with flattering words and gifts,
he would not accept them.
Not accepting them
was also because he disdained to associate with them.
Liu Xiahui did not feel ashamed to serve a corrupt ruler,
nor did he demean himself in a minor office.
When advancing, he did not conceal his talent
and insisted on following his own principles.
If he was passed over and left behind, he did not resent it;
if he was in hardship and poverty, he did not grieve.
Therefore, he said:
“You are you,
and I am I.
Even if you strip naked beside me,
how could you defile me?”
Therefore, he would naturally associate with them
without losing himself.
If pulled to stop, he would stop.
"If pulled to stop, he would stop,"
this also means he did not disdain to leave.
Mencius said:
"Bo Yi was narrow-minded,
and Liu Xia Hui was not respectful.
Narrow-mindedness and disrespect
are not followed by a gentleman."
*Gongsun Chou II*
4.1 Mencius said:
"Timely opportunities given by Heaven are not as important as advantageous terrain,
and advantageous terrain is not as important as the unity of the people.
A city three *li* in circumference
and an outer wall seven *li* in circumference,
when surrounded and attacked, may not be taken.
In surrounding and attacking it,
there must be some who have the advantages of timely opportunities given by Heaven;
however, if they do not succeed,
it is because timely opportunities given by Heaven are not as important as advantageous terrain.
It is not that the walls of the city are not high,
or that the moats are not deep,
"Weapons and armor are not lacking in strength and sharpness,
and grain is not scarce;
yet (the people) abandon and leave them.
This shows that the advantages of terrain are not as important as the harmony of the people.
Therefore, it is said:
'To confine the people does not depend on territorial boundaries;
to secure a state does not depend on the perils of mountains and valleys;
to overawe the world does not depend on the sharpness of weapons and armor.'
He who gains the Way receives much assistance;
he who loses the Way receives little assistance.
To the point of receiving little assistance,
even relatives will betray him;
to the point of receiving much assistance,
the whole world will submit to him.
Using what the whole world submits to,
to attack those whom even relatives betray;
therefore, the gentleman may not fight,
but if he fights, he will surely win."
4.2 Mencius was about to go to court to see the king.
The king sent a man to say,
"I intended to go to see you,
but I have a cold
and cannot be exposed to the wind.
Tomorrow I will hold court,
I don't know if it will be possible for me to see you?"
(Mencius) replied,
"Unfortunately, I am ill
and cannot attend court."
Tomorrow, I will go to offer condolences at the Dongguo family's house.
Gongsun Chou said,
"In the past, you declined due to illness,
but today you are offering condolences.
Perhaps this is not permissible?"
I said,
"In the past I was ill,
but today I am better.
How could I not offer condolences?"
The king sent someone to inquire about my illness,
and a doctor came.
Meng Zhongzi replied,
"In the past, there was a royal order,
but I had the worry of gathering firewood (a euphemism for illness),
and was unable to go to court.
Now my illness is slightly better,
and I am hastening to court.
I don't know if I will be able to make it."
He sent several people to wait for me on the road, saying,
"Please, you must not return home,
but go to court!"
Having no choice, I went to Jing Chou's house to stay overnight.
Master Jing said,
"Within the family, there is father and son;
outside the family, there is lord and subject.
These are the great human relationships.
The relationship between father and son is characterized by kindness,
and the relationship between ruler and subject is characterized by respect.
I have seen your respect for the King’s son,
but I have not seen the way you respect the King.”
Mencius said,
“Alas! What kind of talk is this!
The people of Qi do not use benevolence and righteousness to speak with the King;
is it because they consider benevolence and righteousness not beautiful?
In their hearts they say:
‘What is he worthy of discussing benevolence and righteousness with?’ and that is all.
Then there is no greater disrespect than this.
I dare not present anything before the King except the Way of Yao and Shun,
therefore, among the people of Qi, none are as respectful of the King as I am.”
Jingzi said,
“No;
that is not what I meant.
The rites say:
‘When your father summons, do not say “Yes”;
when the ruler orders a summons, do not wait for the carriage.’
You were originally going to court,
but upon hearing the King's order, you did not go after all.
It seems that this is not in accordance with the rites.”
Mencius said,
“Are you talking about that?
Zengzi said:
‘The wealth of Jin and Chu cannot be matched;
they have their wealth,
I have my benevolence;
He relies on his rank;
I rely on my righteousness.
What dissatisfaction should I have?"
Is it possible that he considered it unrighteous
and yet Zengzi spoke of it?
Perhaps this is a single principle.
In the world, there are three universally respected things:
rank is one,
age is one,
virtue is one.
In the court, nothing is superior to rank;
in the village community, nothing is superior to age;
in assisting the world and governing the people, nothing is superior to virtue.
How can one possess one of these and disregard the other two?
Therefore, a ruler who is about to undertake great things
must have ministers whom he does not summon.
If he wants to consult them, he goes to them.
If his respect for virtue and delight in the Way are not like this,
he will not be capable of achieving great things.
Therefore, Tang, in his relationship with Yi Yin,
learned from him and then made him his minister;
therefore, he became king without toil.
Duke Huan, in his relationship with Guan Zhong,
learned from him and then made him his minister;
therefore, he became hegemon without toil.
Today, the territories of the world are similar, and their virtues are equal;
no one is able to surpass the others.
There is no other reason for this
good ministers are those who are taught,
not good ministers who receive the teaching.
When Tang treated Yi Yin,
or Duke Huan treated Guan Zhong,
they would not dare to summon them.
Even Guan Zhong could not be summoned,
how much less those who are not like Guan Zhong?"
4.3 Chen Zhen asked,
"The other day in Qi,
the king presented one hundred *jian* of gold and you did not accept it;
in Song,
he presented seventy *yi* and you accepted it;
in Xue,
he presented fifty *yi* and you accepted it.
If your refusal the other day was right,
then your acceptance today is wrong;
if your acceptance today is right,
then your refusal the other day was wrong.
The Master must stand by one of these."
Mencius said,
"Both are right.
When I was in Song,
I was about to travel far,
and travelers must have traveling expenses;
they said,
'We present these as traveling expenses.'
Why would I not accept them?
When I was in Xue,
I have a cautious heart;
and declined it, saying:
"I heard of the warning,
so I prepared provisions for the army."
Why should I not accept it?
If I were in Qi,
then there would be a place for it.
To offer provisions when there is no place for them
is to bribe me.
How can there be a gentleman who can be won over by bribes?"
4.4 When Mencius arrived at Pinglu,
he said to its chief official:
"If your soldiers carrying spears
lost their rank three times in a day,
would you dismiss them or not?"
He said:
"Not waiting for three times."
"Then your losing your rank is also frequent.
In years of famine and scarcity,
of your people, the old and weak roll into ditches,
and the strong scatter and go to the four directions;
there are several thousand of them."
He said:
"This is not what Ju Xin could have done."
Mencius said:
"Suppose there is someone who receives another's cattle and sheep
and pastures them for him,
then he will certainly seek pasture and fodder for them.
If one seeks a herdsman and fodder and cannot find them,
should one turn back and blame the people?
Or should one simply stand by and watch them die?"
He said:
"This is the crime of Ju Xin."
Another day, he met with the king and said:
"Of those who serve as administrators for the king,
I know five people.
Of those who know their faults,
only Kong Ju Xin does."
He recited this to the king.
The king said:
"This is my fault."
4.5 Mencius said to Zhi Wa:
"Your resigning from Lingqiu
and requesting the position of judge
seems fitting,
because you can speak out.
Now it has been several months,
can you not speak out?"
Zhi Wa remonstrated with the king but was not heeded,
so he resigned his position and left.
The people of Qi said:
"What he did for Zhi
Wa was good;
but what he did for himself,
I do not understand."
Gong Du Zi told this to Mencius.
